questions.text:
A male patient was brought to the emergency room after a road traffic accident. He produces unrecognizable sounds only, opens his eyes only to a painful stimulus and his right pupil alone is unreactive to light. His posture on the bed is shown below. What is this patient's calculated GCS-P score?

GCS-P: Glasgow coma scale - pupils.
questions.solution:
The above patient has a GCS-P score of 6 which is calculated as follows.

The score for eye-opening - opens only to painful stimulus - 2
The score for verbal response - sounds only - 2
The score for motor response - decorticate posturing - 3
Pupillary score - one pupil non-reactive - 1

GCS-P score - 

It is the Glasgow Coma Scale score with the incorporation of pupillary function. The pupillary function was added so that the brainstem function is also represented by the score. 

The total score is calculated by adding the score for eye-opening, verbal, and motor responses and subtracting the pupil score from the sum.

Total score = 2 + 2 + 3 - 1 = 6

Decorticate posture:

  • The upper limbs are flexed, the lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended.
  • Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response in Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture:

  • Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. 
  • Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, his pulse rate was 120 bpm, BP 80/40 mmHg, and the extremities were cold. Which of the given peripheral cannulas will you use during the resuscitation of this patient?
questions.solution:
For trauma patients who necessitate a high volume of fluid replacement and multiple blood transfers large-sized, wide-bored cannulas are preferred. Among the given options, an 18G size (green) cannula would be appropriate (larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number).

In the above image, the cannulae numbered 1 to 4 are respectively:

  1. 18G - green
  2. 20G - pink
  3. 22G - blue
  4. 24G - yellow

Hypovolemic shock is frequently caused by hemorrhage which can be external due to trauma or internal. The most common cause of internal hemorrhage leading to hypovolemic shock is gastrointestinal bleeding. Massive burns and vomiting are other causes of hypovolemic shock. 

The goal of care in this scenario is to improve volume status which can be done through the placement of large-bore intravenous lines (16 gauge or 18 gauge) and administering fluids.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. You notice that the senior resident uses the trauma scoring system which involves the energy of the injury as one of the components. Which of the following trauma scoring systems is being used here?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A postoperative patient comes for a follow-up visit to have his sutures removed. Which of the following blades will you use?
questions.solution:
A number-12 blade is used for suture removal.

A 12-size blade is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

The number on a surgical blade communicates both its size and its shape. The different surgical blades are shown below:

Other options:

Option A: The 11-size blade has an oblique edge with a sharp-pointed tip and hence it is known as a "stab knife". 

Uses:

  • Commonly used to incise skin, subcutaneous tissue, and deep fascia to open the abscess cavity in a single stroke, during incision and drainage (I & D) of an abscess.
  • This blade can also be used for inserting drains and arteriotomy.

Option C: The 15-size blade has a narrow shaft and is often used for minor surgical procedures. 

Uses of 15-scalpel blade:

  • To make precise skin incisions in dermatosurgery
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Select ocular procedures (15C blade)
  • Select plastic surgery procedures (15C blade)

Option D: The 10-size blade is used for skin incisions.

Note: The 22-size blade is often used for abdominal incisions. Essentially a larger version of the number 10, it has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a short, curved cutting edge. These blades are best for creating large incisions, often through thick skin. Surgical blades no. 20, 21, 22, 23, and 24 have a wide shaft and are used for larger incisions.

questions.text: A screening mammogram in a 50-year-old woman showed diffuse microcalcification. Needle biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ. What should be the ideal treatment?
questions.solution:
Diffuse microcalcifications are associated with high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (HG-DCIS) and should be treated with simple mastectomy.

DCIS may be classified using the Van Nuys system, which combines the patient’s age, type of DCIS and presence of microcalcification, the extent of resection margin, and size of disease. Patients with higher scores benefit from radiotherapy after excision, whereas those of low grade, whose tumor is completely excised, need no further treatment.

A score ranging from 1 (lesions with the best prognosis) to 3 (lesions with the worst prognosis) is given for each of the four prognostic predictors. Total scores range from 4 (least likely to recur) to 12 (most likely to recur).

Margin(mm) ≥10 1-9 <1
Class Grade 1 or 2 without necrosis Grade 1 or 2 with necrosis Grade 3 with or without necrosis
Age(years) >60 40-60 <40
  • Scores 4-6 and score 7 with ≥3mm margin: Excision alone 
  • Score 7 with <3 mm margin, score 8 with ≥3mm margin, score 9 with ≥5mm margin: Excision with RT
  • Score 8 with <3 mm margin, score 9 with <5 mm margin & score 10-12: Mastectomy

The type of microcalcification seen on mammography also helps in determining the grade of DCIS. While the linear branching type of microcalcification is associated with high-grade-DCIS, the fine granular type is associated with low-grade DCIS. Simple mastectomy needs to be performed for high-grade DCIS to prevent local recurrence.

Other indications of simple mastectomy in DCIS include:

  • Diffuse microcalcifications (extensive disease)
  • Multicentric disease
  • Inability to obtain clear margins with breast-conserving surgery
  • Likelihood of a poor cosmetic result after breast-conserving surgery
  • Contraindications to radiation therapy

questions.text: A patient who had undergone a thyroidectomy suddenly develops dyspnea with stridor. On examination, he had tachycardia and hypotension. Management of this case includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The above scenario is likely due to the development of a hematoma post-thyroidectomy. Hematoma formation post-thyroidectomy is managed by all the above methods except the administration of propylthiouracil. Propylthiouracil is used for the treatment of thyrotoxic crises.

Hematoma formation post-thyroidectomy occurs due to the slipping of ligatures of the superior thyroid artery, other pedicles, or small veins. This leads to venous edema of the larynx and can cause airway obstruction and respiratory distress.

Clinically, patients will have tachycardia, hypotension, breathlessness, stridor, and respiratory obstruction due to tension hematoma under strap muscles.

It is a life-threatening complication and should be monitored in the first 24 hours after surgery. As first aid, immediate release of sutures including deep fascia has to be done and pressure over the trachea is released. Then the patient is shifted to the operation theatre and under general anesthesia re-exploration is done and bleeders are ligated.

Laryngeal edema may occur due to a hematoma with tension, intubation injury, and surgical trauma. In this condition, along with evacuation of the hematoma, endotracheal intubation is also needed immediately to avoid airway obstruction. If it is impossible to intubate, a needle tracheostomy using a 12-gauge needle (2.3 mm diameter) is done temporarily.

Complications of thyroidectomy:

  • Hemorrhage - most common complication overall
  • Nerve injury 
    • External laryngeal nerve - hoarseness (more common)
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - hoarseness if unilateral, life-threatening aspiration and aphonia if bilateral
  • Respiratory obstruction
    • Laryngeal edema - the most common cause of respiratory obstruction
    • Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
    • Laryngomalacia
    • Tension hematoma
  • Hypoparathyroidism - infarction of parathyroids
  • Thyroid storm - inadequately prepared for surgery
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Recurrent thyrotoxicosis
  • Wound infection, stitch granuloma, keloid.

questions.text:
Match the following surgical procedures with the corresponding conditions for which they are performed:
Procedure Condition

1. Ramstedt's procedure

A. Peyronie's disease

2. Nesbitt procedure

 B. Biliary atresia

3. Heller's operation

 C. Infantile-hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

4. Kasai procedure

 D. Achalasia cardia
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

  1. Ramstedt's procedure - Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  2. Nesbitt procedure - Peyronie's disease
  3. Heller's operation - Achalasia cardia
  4. Kasai procedure - Biliary atresia

Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy is performed by a laparoscopic or open supraumbilical incision for the treatment of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

Nesbitt procedure is the most commonly used procedure for treating Peyronie's disease. It corrects the deformity by plicating the convex side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Heller's Myotomy is done for achalasia cardia. It involves cutting the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia of the stomach. It is often combined with a partial anterior fundoplication (Heller-Dor procedure) to avoid the complication of gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. In this procedure, radical excision of all bile duct tissues up to the liver capsule is performed. A Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding the current American cancer society (ACS) colorectal cancer screening recommendations for the average-risk population?
  1. Screening should begin at the age of 55 years
  2. An annual fecal occult blood test (FOBT)
  3. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years
  4. Double-contrast barium enema (DCBE) every 2 years
  5. Colonoscopy every 10 years
questions.solution:
An annual faecal occult blood test (FOBT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or colonoscopy every 10 years are the recommended tests according to the current American Cancer Society (ACS) colorectal screening guidelines for the average-risk population.

Current ACS guidelines advocate screening the average-risk population for colorectal carcinoma beginning at age 50 years. Screening recommendations include the following:

  1. Annual faecal occult blood test (FOBT), or
  2. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or
  3. FOBT and flexible sigmoidoscopy in combination every 5 years, or
  4. Air-contrast barium enema every 5 years, or
  5. Colonoscopy every 10 years.

A positive FOBT should be followed by a colonoscopy.

Patients with other risk factors (considered a high-risk population) should be screened earlier and more frequently, as shown below:

Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis) At diagnosis; then 8 years after diagnosis for pancolitis; 15 years after diagnosis for left-sided colitis. Colonoscopy with multiple biopsies every 1–2 years

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.solution:
A patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria and the abdominal X-ray showing homogenous ground glass-like calcification is suggestive of a putty kidney.

The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB). It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is always a secondary TB (reinfection or reactivation of old TB). Genitourinary TB usually presents as sterile pyuria.

Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. Microbiological diagnosis is confirmed by at least 3 consecutive early-morning urine samples showing acid-fast bacilli using Ziehl–Neelsen (ZN) stain and subsequently cultured (gold standard).

GUTB is treated with a short course of anti-tubercular therapy (ATT). Ureteric strictures require double J stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy. Definitive treatment is after 3-6mn of ATT, where a reconstructive procedure (open surgical repair > balloon dilatation) is performed. In case the kidney is poorly functioning, a nephrectomy is done.

Option B: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, seen in hypercalcemic conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

Option C: Staghorn calculus (a triple phosphate stone) is found in urinary tract infections (UTI) by urease-producing pathogens like proteus and is not a cause of sterile pyuria.

Option D: Psoas calcification is a muscle calcification that develops after acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis. It is not associated with sterile pyuria.

questions.text: A 41-year-old male patient who is diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma(RCC) undergoes nephrectomy. The histopathological image of the tumor is shown below. What is the subtype of RCC?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation and histology specimen showing round or polygonal tumor cells with clear cytoplasm is suggestive of clear cell carcinoma. 

Clear cell carcinoma is the most common renal cell carcinoma. The growth pattern of clear cell carcinomas varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular. Cells are round or polygonal in shape. The cytoplasm is clear or granular and it contains glycogen and lipid.

Clear cell carcinoma mostly arises from the proximal tubular epithelium. It is associated with the loss of the short arm of chromosome 3. The VHL gene (tumor suppressor gene) is located on chromosome 3p.

Clear cell carcinomas are usually single and unilateral. They are spherical masses that vary in size. Composed of yellow-colored tissue that distorts the renal outline. The yellow color is due to the accumulation of lipids in tumor cells.

The most common risk factors of renal cell carcinoma are tobacco usage, obesity, hypertension, and unopposed estrogen therapy. 

Other options:

Option B:  Papillary carcinoma arises from distal convoluted tubules. They can be multifocal and bilateral. The most common cytogenetic abnormalities associated are trisomies 7, 17 and loss of Y. Tumor cells are cuboidal or low columnar cells arranged in papillary formation with psammoma bodies as shown below.

Option C:  Chromophobe carcinoma arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. Tumor cells have pale eosinophilic cytoplasm with a halo around the nucleus and prominent cell membranes as shown below.

Option D: Collecting duct carcinoma is a rare type of renal cell carcinoma that arises from the collecting duct cells in the medulla. They show irregular channels lined by atypical epithelium with a hobnail pattern(Hobnail-shaped cells protruding into the glandular lumen marked by arrow) as shown below.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A patient complaining of pain in the right flank has been diagnosed with right-sided renal calculi measuring 2.2cm. Urine microscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most suitable treatment for this patient?

choices.text: No treatment required just pain management suffices

questions.solution:
The image of the urine microscopy shows hexagonal-shaped cystine stones. Hence the best suitable treatment for this patient with cystine renal calculi measuring 2.2 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Cystine stone is relatively resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy and a stone size of more than 2 cm necessitates percutaneous nephrolithotomy. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy is done until the renal stone size of less than 1.5cm.

PCNL is indicated in the following condition:

  • If the patient has anatomical obstruction like pelviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula, or distal ureteral obstruction.
  • Hard renal stones like cystine stones, and calcium oxalate stones.
  • If the renal stone is struvite stone as it is associated with urinary tract infection.

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment.

Complications of ESWL include infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma. ESWL is contraindicated in obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Note: Stone fragments collected in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 18-month-old son to OPD with complaints of repeated urinary tract infections. During diagnostic work-up, pelvic USG shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the USG showing the key-hole sign is suggestive of the posterior urethral valve (PUV). It is seen due to dilatation of the bladder and the proximal urethra.

The posterior urethral valves are membranes that have a small posterior slit, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. They function as flap valves and are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow.

The posterior urethral valve is the most common congenital cause of bladder outlet obstruction in males. PUV is classified into three types based on Young's classification.

Diagnosis is made antenatally with ultrasound, which demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder. If the diagnosis is not made antenatally, then neonates typically present with urinary infection or uremia and renal failure. 

The investigation of choice for a posterior urethral valve is micturating cystourethrography (MCUG).

Initially, the obstruction is relieved by catheterization to preserve renal function. Definitive treatment is by urethroscopic destruction of the valves with lifelong supportive treatment.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. He had sustained a pelvic fracture and injured his perineum and is unable to pass urine. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the meatus and on digital rectal examination, there is a high-riding prostate. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
The site of injury, in this case, is the membranous urethra.

Membranous urethra rupture is most commonly caused by a pelvic fracture. Pelvic fracture is most commonly caused by road traffic accident. Clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus and on digital rectal examination, there will be a high riding prostate called as vermooten sign . Marked bruising of the penis, scrotum and pubic area is commonly associated.

Urethrogram with water-soluble contrast is used for confirmation of the diagnosis. 

Management is by inserting a suprapubic catheter. If there is an associated bladder rupture, the bladder will not be seen on the ultrasound, and management in such a case is by exploration, repair, and placement of a suprapubic catheter.

Other options:

Option A: Bulbar urethral injury is the most common type of urethral injury. It occurs when there is a blow to the perineum. It occurs commonly due to straddle injury (cycling accidents, loose manhole covers, and gymnasium accidents). Clinical features include perineal bruising, butterfly hematoma, bleeding from urethral meatus, and retention of urine is present.

Option C: Penile urethral injury is a type of distal urethral injury caused due to straddle injury. Clinical features are same as bulbar urethral injury. 

Option D: Urinary bladder rupture can be intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is the most common. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on the distended bladder. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt abdominal trauma. On examination, he was hemodynamically stable. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) showed splenic trauma with a subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area with ongoing hemorrhage. Angiography and embolization were done but failed to achieve hemostasis. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management is splenorrhaphy. 

The non-expanding subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area is suggestive of grade II splenic injury. These patients are managed by angiography and embolization, and if it fails, the next step in management is a spleen-saving technique or splenorrhaphy.

Splenorrhaphy is a procedure done to preserve the spleen parenchyma. These involve all the surgical procedures done to save the spleen parenchyma while splenectomy is the entire surgical removal of the viscera. Splenorrhaphy should not be performed if the patient is unstable if there are multiple injuries or extensive splenic injury. 

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT.

If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Other options: 

Option A: Repeat angiography and embolization are unlikely to help as it has already failed once in this patient. 

Option B: Conservative management will not stop the ongoing hemorrhage that is present in this patient. It is useful in patients who are no longer bleeding. 

Option C: Splenectomy is not required in this patient as they have a grade II injury and are still hemodynamically stable.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A male patient is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis. Intraoperative cholangiography shows a complete transection of the common bile duct without loss of ductal length. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The intraoperative cholangiography shows complete transection of the common bile duct without loss of a segment. This is managed with T-tube placement.

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the most common cause of bile duct injury. Biliary injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy results from failure to define the surgical anatomy owing to visual perceptual error. 

Clinically, patients with post-cholecystectomy bile duct injury present with right upper quadrant pain, fever, nausea, and jaundice (in case of strictures).

Investigations show leukocytosis and elevated liver enzymes (ALP and GGT). The use of cholangiography helps in delineating the management of bile duct injuries during cholecystectomy.

When a bile duct injury is detected during surgery, the laparoscopic cholecystectomy is changed to an open procedure. If a major injury is discovered and an experienced surgeon is unavailable, an external drain is placed, and the patient is transferred to a referral center.

Benign lesions

  • Well demarcated homogenous hyperechoic mass
  • Hypoechoic in presence of fatty infiltration of the liver

  • Variable echogenicity

  • Arterial phase: Hyperdense
  • Portal venous phase: Typically isodense

  • Poorly defined margin with coarse and irregular internal echoes

questions.text: An 11-month-old baby boy with right side undescended testis is referred by a pediatrician to your urology outpatient.  Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. But a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. Ultrasonography revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal with a normal left testis. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of cryptorchidism and the next best step is to perform an orchidopexy.

Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for incompletely palpable unilateral undescended testis. Orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age.

About 4% of boys are born with one or both testes incompletely descended. About two-thirds of these reach the scrotum during the first 3 months of life, but full descent after that is uncommon.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells 
Other options:

Option A: Cryptorchidism is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma). Thus, observation is never the policy.
 
Option B: When the testis is not palpable, ultrasound may be helpful in identifying the intracanalicular testis, while laparoscopy may be needed to differentiate between the abdominal testis and a truly absent testis. Since here testis is made out in the inguinal region, laparoscopy is not the next best line of management.
 
Option D: Orchidectomy should be considered if the incompletely descended testis is atrophic, particularly in the postpubertal boy if the other testis is normal.

Hence, orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age to avoid the following complications remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

  • T- Torsion

  • E- Epididymorchitis

  • S- Sterility

  • T- Trauma (Increased risk)

  • I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

  • S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm

questions.solution:
Surgery is indicated in an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) only if its diameter is more than 55 mm in a male patient. 

If the diameter is less than 55 mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55 mm.

Indications for surgery in abdominal aortic aneurysm:

  • Size >5.5 cm in males 
  • Size >5 cm in females 
  • Expansion of >1 cm in one year 
  • Painful tender aneurysm 
  • Thrombosed aneurysm; aneurysm with distal emboli

Management of aortic aneurysm: AAA is surgically managed by dacron graft repair. It can be either open or EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair) 

  • Open surgical repair is done by exposing the aorta through a mid-sternal incision and graft replacement. To expose the aorta the descending colon should be mobilized medially and this is known as left visceral rotation or Mattox procedure.
  • EVAR is a minimally invasive procedure in which an aortic stent graft is placed on the nonaneurysmal aortoiliac segment.

Complications following an AAA repair are:

  • Cardiovascular (ischemia and infarction)
  • Respiratory (atelectasis or consolidation).
  • Colonic ischemia.
  • Renal failure.
  • Aortoduodenal fistula
  • spinal cord ischemia

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is Whipple's procedure. 

The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure:

  • Distal stomach
  • Duodenum
  • Proximal jejunum
  • Head of the pancreas
  • Gallbladder
  • Common bile duct (CBD)
  • Regional lymphatics

The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when:

  • The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Tumour encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach
  • A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy

Other options: 

Option B: In Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option C: Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

The Kasai procedure or Roux-en-Y hepato-porto-enterostomy is shown in the image below.

Option D: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30 - 50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

A 42-year-old teacher visited the OPD for an annual checkup. On examination, prominent tortuous, dilated subcutaneous veins are present on the medial side of her lower leg with the CEAP classification C2a Ep As Pn. She is aware of her varicose veins and is asymptomatic. She is wondering if treatment is required at this stage. What is the next step in management?

CEAP - Clinical - Etiology - Anatomy - Pathophysiology classification of varicose veins
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mild asymptomatic varicose veins according to the CEAP classification. Therefore, the next step in management is compression stockings.

In addition, she has no venous complications like pigmentation, eczema, or venous ulcers. Thus, she can be initially managed with compression stockings. 

Compression stockings provide external pressure to the limb which compresses the veins and improves venous return. There are two lengths available - knee or thigh length. However, knee-length stockings are commonly prescribed as they have better compliance. 

They are useful for the initial management of varicose veins as they relieve symptoms and are a conservative approach. If the varicose veins become symptomatic or become visually distressing then non-conservative approaches described below can be considered. 

Other options: 

Option A: Radiofrequency ablation uses electromagnetic currents to destroy the vein without damaging the other structures. It can only treat junctional and truncal incompetence and not varicosities. 

Option B: Saphenopopliteal ligation is a surgical procedure where the saphenopopliteal junction is dissected with flush ligation. Alternatively, the small saphenous vein can also be ligated as proximally as possible. Sural nerve neuropraxia and common peroneal nerve injury are possible complications. 

Option C: Saphenofemoral ligation is a surgical procedure made where the great saphenous vein is ligated and stripped. There are complications associated with this procedure such as saphenous nerve injury and neovascularization due to trauma leading to reoccurrence.

questions.text: A young patient who suffered a large wound due to a road traffic accident was referred to you after initial wound management. As a plastic surgeon, you decide to cover the wound with the following type of graft. Which of the following is not a feature of the graft used by the plastic surgeon?

choices.text: It is also known as Thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
This graft has the best cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife. The best cosmetic appearance is generally seen with full-thickness skin grafts. 

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or dermatome knife.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

 

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: A mother with polyhydramnios delivered a baby at term gestation. She was unable to feed the baby as it choked on the milk. She also noticed the baby's abdomen appeared distended. Vesicular breath sounds in bilateral lung fields and abdominal distension were noted on examination. An attempt to pass a nasogastric tube fails. An X-ray is ordered and appears as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of choking and abdominal distention with a failure to pass a nasogastric tube and an X-ray showing NG tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas suggests the presence of a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. Among the different types, Type C is the most common type. It consists of proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. With each breath, the air enters the distal esophagus and the stomach causing gastric distention which presents as abdominal distention. 

Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube is a crucial pointer in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia. 

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.


Other options:

Option A - Foreign body in the trachea will present with decreased air entry bilaterally in the lungs and stridor.

Option B - Gastric volvulus may also be associated with abdominal distension and difficulty in passing the NG tube into the stomach. However, in this case, the tube is seen stuck in the proximal esophagus itself making the diagnosis of TEF more likely.

Option D - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is usually left-sided and presents with respiratory distress. On examination, bowel sounds are heard in the chest field as abdominal contents herniate into the chest. There is a scaphoid abdomen rather than a distended abdomen as in this case.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: As a surgeon, you plan to perform the following surgeries on four of your patients. In which of the following procedures will you be extra cautious due to the higher risk of surgical site infection (SSI)?
questions.solution:
Extra precautions should be taken while performing a colorectal surgery as it belongs to the category of clean-contaminated wound (class II) with an expected infection rate of 4-14%.

Elective cholecystectomy also belongs to the category of clean-contaminated wound (class II) but it is associated with a lesser infection rate of 2-9%

Class I: Clean wounds: Surgical site infection (SSI) rate is least in clean wounds, i.e. in operations where there is no inflammation and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Examples include:

  • Elective herniorrhaphy is a clean wound categorized as class I (as the prosthetic mesh is placed)
  • Breast biopsy 

Class II: Clean-contaminated wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination. Examples include:

  • Elective cholecystectomy
  • Elective gastrointestinal surgeries (eg: Fundoplication)
  • Colorectal surgery (higher infection rate)

Class III: Contaminated wounds include open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract; and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered.

Class IV: Dirty wounds include old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera.

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient was admitted to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, paradoxical respiration was seen. His chest X-ray is shown below. He was given analgesics and oxygen was administered via face mask but he developed respiratory failure. What is the best line of management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario alongwith the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggest Flail chest.

Flail chest is characterized by contiguous rib fractures and paradoxical respiration following blunt trauma to the chest wall. Mechanical ventilation (like Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is the management of flail chest with respiratory failure.

Flail Chest :

  • A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, i.e. 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places.
  • The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well.

Clinical Features:

On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and less air, therefore, moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards(paradoxical respiration).

Diagnosis - To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for the paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement, and the associated lung contusion are all causes of hypoxia and respiratory failure.

The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Treatment

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia and physiotherapy.
  • IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Other options:

Option A: Chest tube drainage can be done in traumatic pulmonary contusion associated with pneumothorax or hemothorax

Option B: Intrapleural local analgesia can be given if the patient has a chest tube inserted. Since the chest tube drainage is only done after stabilising the patient, intrapleural analgesia is not the best line of treatment at this stage.

Option D: Surgical fixation of the fracture is done only in patients with severe chest injury and pulmonary contusion. Also, surgery should be proceeded only after the patient's condition is stabilised.

questions.text:
A chronic alcoholic patient presented with acute epigastric pain radiating to the back. On examination, the following sign is seen as shown in the image below. Lab investigations showed elevated serum amylase and lipase. What are the possible complications of the underlying condition?
  1. Coeliac artery thrombosis
  2. Pseudocyst formation
  3. Splenic vein thrombosis
  4. Sterile necrotic collection
  5. Infected necrotic collection
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the grey turner's sign (discoloration of the flanks) are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. All the above-mentioned options could be possible complications except celiac artery thrombosis.

Acute pancreatitis can result in local and systemic complications. Local complications develop after the first week of the event and include:

Complication Description Management
Pancreatic pseudocyst
  • A well-encapsulated amylase-rich fluid collection outside the pancreas formed around 4 weeks after an attack of pancreatitis.
  • The fluid shows low CEA levels and cytology shows inflammatory cells.
  • Spontaneous resolution is common
  • Asymptomatic chronic thick-walled cysts may necessitate endoscopic, surgical, or percutaneous drainage due to the risk of complications. 
Acute peripancreatic fluid collection (APFC)
  •  A collection of sterile fluid in the peripancreatic tissues without encapsulation.

Usually resolves without any intervention but a large fluid collection may necessitate imaging-guided aspiration and drainage.
Sterile and infected pancreatic necrosis
  • Diffuse or localized peripancreatic fat breakdown results in a necrotic collection within and around the pancreas - acute necrotic collection(ANC).
  • The collection consists of fluid and necrotic material with an ill-defined wall that may be initially sterile but later become infected.
  • Over a period of time, the capsule is well formed and called a walled Off necrosis (WON).
 Management includes conservative measures and percutaneous drainage. In patients with overwhelming sepsis, laparotomy may be needed to perform a necrosectomy. Continuous post-operative closed lavage may be needed to prevent a recurrence.
Splenic vein thrombosis As a result of the procoagulant state during acute pancreatitis. Anti-platelet drugs. Endoscopic banding and beta blockers are used in the case of portal hypertension.

 
Pancreatic abscess A circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus around the pancreas. Imaging-guided percutaneous drainage under the cover of antibiotics
Pancreatic ascites

A generalized peritoneal effusion resulting from pancreatic duct disruption.

Amylase-rich fluid will be obtained through paracentesis.

 Imaging guided drainage with wide-bore drains
Hemorrhage Bleeding into the pseudocyst cavity or from a raw surface or pseudoaneurysm arising from a peripancreatic vessel. Embolization or surgery


The image given below shows pancreatic pseudocyst on a CT scan.

Systemic complications result from multi-organ damage and include acute respiratory distress syndrome, pleural effusions, gastrointestinal hemorrhage, renal failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: Vascular complications of pancreatitis

Arterial pseudoaneurysm:

  • It is caused by damage to the vessel wall by pancreatic elastase
  • The most common vessel affected is the splenic artery, but the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), cystic artery, and gastroduodenal artery (GDA) may also be affected
  • Spontaneous rupture results in massive bleeding
  • Clinical manifestations include sudden onset of abdominal pain, tachycardia, and hypotension.
  • CT angiography is the investigation of choice
  • Treatment
    • Arterial embolization
    • Ligation of the affected vessel in refrac­tory cases

Vascular thrombosis:

  • The vessel usually affected is the splenic vein, but in severe cases, it can extend into the portal venous system
  • Clinical features include splenomegaly, gastric varices, and splenic vein occlusion
  • Treatment:
    • Mostly conservative
    • Throm­bolytics in the acute early phase

questions.text:
Match the following features with their corresponding syndromes

 

Features Syndrome
A. Pheochromocytomas, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, parathyroid hyperplasia 1. MEN 1
B. Parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, adrenal tumor, testicular tumor 2. MEN 2A

C. Mucosal neuromas, Marfanoid habitus, pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

 3. MEN 2B
D. Hyperparathyroidism, gastrinomas, prolactinomas  4. MEN 4
questions.solution:
The correct matched option is A-2, B-4, C-3, and D-1.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) refers to a group of inherited syndromes including various benign and malignant tumors of endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic. 

MEN 1 is a syndrome complex associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A comprises mainly medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B/3 consists of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic at 17 weeks of gestational age with a history of a lump in her left breast for the past 3 months. On examination, you find a lump of 2 X 2 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and can detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes.

USG is preferred in pregnant women, lactating women, and young women (less than 40 years) since breast tissue is dense in these populations.

Other options:

Option A) Mammography is less useful in young women due to the increased density of breast tissue.

Option B) MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in high risk cases where metastasis or spread to other breast is suspected.

Option D) Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not recommended in pregnant women. It is difficult to distinguish breast cancer from the normal cellular proliferation in the breast tissue due to hormonal changes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man met with an accident and sustained a pelvic fracture. He developed haematuria. Retrograde cystourethrogram showed extraperitoneal bladder rupture. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The usual line of management of extraperitoneal bladder rupture is catheter drainage for 10 days.

Bladder injury can be intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal. Extraperitoneal injuries are more common and are usually associated with pelvic fractures. Intraperitoneal injuries are caused by penetrating injuries or rupture at the dome of a full bladder due to a blow or fall. The symptoms of extraperitoneal bladder injury are suprapubic pain with the inability to void.

CT cystography is the ideal investigation for bladder injury. Retrograde cystography confirms the diagnosis. On retrograde cystogram, a dense, flame-shaped pattern of extravasation of contrast in the pelvis is seen in extraperitoneal bladder rupture.

Management of extraperitoneal rupture of the bladder:

Uncomplicated extraperitoneal bladder injury is usually managed with urethral catheter drainage only. Emergency operative management of bladder injury is done in:

  • Intraperitoneal injury from external trauma
  • Penetrating or iatrogenic non-urologic injury
  • Inadequate bladder drainage or clots in urine
  • Bladder neck injury
  • Rectal or vaginal injury
  • Open pelvic fracture
  • Pelvic fracture requiring open reduction and internal fixation
  • Selected stable patients undergoing laparotomy for other reasons 
  • Bone fragments projecting into the bladder

questions.text: A neonate presented with features of respiratory distress, tachypnea, and recurrent pulmonary infections.  A chest x-ray revealed the following finding. All of the following are incorrect statements about the likely condition except

choices.text: The most commonly involved viscus is the colon
The hernia is posterolateral in location
Majority of the cases are left sided
It is more symptomatic than Bochdalek variant

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the chest X-ray showing an opacity in the right cardiophrenic angle are suggestive of Morgagni hernia in which the colon is the most commonly involved viscus.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia results due to the failure of various structures forming the diaphragm to fuse. It occurs in 1/2000 births. The defect allows abdominal viscera to enter the pleural cavity. It is most frequently caused by the failure of one or both of the pleuroperitoneal membranes to fuse. 

Types:

i) Morgagni hernia.

Here the defect is anteromedial location. It is rarer than Bochdalek hernia and accounts for only 2-5% of CDH. About 90% of the cases occur on the right side.

It is less symptomatic than bochdalek hernia and the diagnosis is usually delayed until childhood. The patient presents with respiratory or upper GI symptoms. Respiratory symptoms like distress, tachypnea, and recurrent pulmonary infections are common in children. Other symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspnea, flatulence, and indigestion.

Radiographic findings

  • Radiolucent paracardiac shadow may be seen retrosternally on lateral chest x-ray if there is bowel herniation.
  • Rounded opacity in the right cardiophrenic angle may be seen if there is herniation of omentum or solid organs.
  • A CT scan may be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Surgical repair is indicated in all cases either by a thoracic or abdominal approach.

 ii) Bochdalek hernia

 It is more common than Morgagni hernia. Here the defect is posterolateral in location. Respiratory distress is experienced by most infants. In the pediatric age group, symptoms are predominantly respiratory due to pulmonary hypoplasia. In adults, it is usually asymptomatic and is incidentally found. About 85% of the cases are left-sided. 

The following is an X-ray showing Morgagni's Hernia 

The following X-ray shows Bochdalek hernia

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)
 

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A patient is admitted for evaluation of recurrent deep venous thrombosis. There is no history of any medical illness. All of the following investigations can be done for evaluating this patient except:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of recurrent DVT in a patient warrants further investigation of the cause of deep venous thrombosis (DVT). DVT can occur in hypercoagulable states caused by either deficiency of protein C or antithrombin III or factor V of Leiden mutation.

Antibodies to factor VIII causes deficiency of factor VIII leading to haemophilia (bleeding disorder).

Deep vein thrombosis:

 i.   Sites:

  1. Pelvic veins
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (common on the left side).

ii.   Features of DVT:

  • Fever- earliest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s, or Neuhof’s signs
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

iii.   Treatment:

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with
  • crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight
  • Warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

iv.   Investigations:

  • Venous Doppler with duplex scanning
  • Haemogram with platelet count
  • D-dimer assays
  • MR Venography 
  • Ventilation-perfusion scanning

Choice of prophylaxis: 

  • Major trauma, abdominal and orthopedic surgeries warrants a longer duration of postoperative immobilization. The pharmacological method is efficacious in these situations.

  • Patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours after minor trauma, operations are at low risk for the development of venous thrombosis. The mechanical method is advised in these situations. The simplest method is for the patient to walk. Activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was brought unconscious to the emergency room. CT brain reveals the following findings. All of the following are indications for performing an open craniotomy in this patient except?

choices.text: A GCS drop of 4 points in a comatose patient
A GCS drop of 6 points  in a comatose patient

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the plain computed tomography (CT) scan shows a concavo-convex-shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma (SDH). A midline shift > 5mm is considered an indication for performing an open craniotomy.

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH.

On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion (as seen in this question)

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  1. Thickness >1 cm
  2. Midline shift >5 mm

Emergent decompression is also recommended to a comatose patient with an acute subdural hematoma less than 1 cm in thickness causing a midline shift of less than 5 mm if any of the following criteria are met:

  •  GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to the hospitalization
  •  The patient presents with fixed and dilated pupils
  • ICP is >20mm Hg

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Presence of which of the following is a contraindication for surgical resection of the tumor in a patient with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas?

choices.text: Lymph node metastases within operative field

questions.solution:
The presence of liver metastasis is a contraindication for surgical resection of the tumor in carcinoma of the head of the pancreas.

If the tumor minimally invades the portal or superior mesenteric vein, this is not a contraindication to surgery (as part of the vein can be resected if necessary), but complete encasement and occlusion of the vein is a contraindication for resection.

The CT shows pancreatic carcinoma involving adjacent structures. 

In any jaundiced patient, the usual workup including liver function tests and ultrasound must be done. If ultrasound shows dilated bile ducts and strong suspicion of cancer of the pancreas is present, then a contrast-enhanced CT scan is advised. 

Indications for resection include : 

  • Cystic tumors 
  • Tumors of ampulla
  • Neuroendocrine tumors
  • No vascular encasement
  • Lymph node metastasis close to the pancreatic head

Contraindications for surgical resection include:

  • Hepatic metastases
  • Peritoneal metastases
  • Lymph node metastases distant from pancreatic head
  • Encasement of 
    • Superior mesenteric artery 
    • Coeliac artery 
    • Hepatic artery 

Tumour size, continuous invasion of the duodenum, stomach or colon, and lymph node metastases within the operative field are not contraindications.
