questions.text:
Arrange the following colour codes used in triage in the increasing order of priority starting with the least priority.
  1. Red
  2. Black 
  3. Yellow
  4. Green
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of triage color coding priority is black (least priority) -> Green -> Yellow -> Red(Highest Priority)

Triage means ‘to sort’ and is essential in the management of mass casualties. It aims to identify the patients in whom treatment at the earliest produces the maximum benefit. It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. 

Priority Colour Medical need Clinical status
First (I) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if the treatment given early
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive if the treatment given within hours
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Note: Reverse triage is used in a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more, allowing for faster turnover. It is followed in this situation to discharge existing patients and to increase the surge capacity of the hospital to accommodate for the natural disaster. Here, non-emergent patients currently admitted to the hospital are discharged to allow for the acute increase in incoming patients.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought to the outpatient department for a facial defect. On examination, the following findings were noticed. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft lip repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side. The most appropriate management for this patient would be a cleft lip repair at 4-6 months.

Etiology of the cleft lip can include familial, protein and vitamin deficiency, rubella infection, radiation, chromosomal abnormalities, maternal epilepsy and drug intake during pregnancy (steroids/eptoin/diazepam)

Majority of the cases are unilateral and cleft lip alone is uncommon.

Millard Criteria (Rule of 10) is used to undertake surgery for cleft lip.

  • 10 pound in weight
  • 10 weeks old
  • 10g% Hemoglobin

Millard cleft lip repair by rotating the local nasolabial flaps is done.

The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months. 

According to Delaire timing of cleft surgery - unilateral cleft lip alone can be operated in one stage operation and is done at 4-6 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with a history of chronic smoking presented with Intermittent calf pain. Angiography shows an inverted tree-like appearance of arteries of both lower limbs. All of the following clinical features can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given scenario is thromboangiitis obliterans / Buerger disease. Acrocyanosis is persistent, painless cyanosis seen in fingers and often in legs with paraesthesia and chilblains affecting young females. It has no association with TAO.

Buerger's disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the lower extremities. It is characterized by occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome.

Clinical features:

  • Common in male smokers below 40 years of age group
  • Intermittent claudication in foot and calf progressing to rest pain, ulceration, gangrene.
  • Recurrent migratory superficial thrombophlebitis.
  • Absent/feeble pulses distal to proximal; dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, popliteal, femoral arteries.
  • May present as Raynaud’s phenomenon.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon is episodic vasospasm. It leads to a sequence of clinical features called Raynaud’s syndrome comprising of local syncope, local asphyxia, and local recovery.

Raynaud’s phenomenon

Acrocyanosis

Episodic

Persistent

Painful

Painless

Acute arteriolar spasm

Chronic constriction

Ischaemic changes are common

Ischaemic changes are not seen

Investigations:

  • Arterial doppler and duplex scan (doppler + B-mode U/S).
  • Transfemoral retrograde angiogram through Seldinger technique shows blockage—sites, extent, and severity
    • The corkscrew appearance of the vessel is due to dilatation of vasa vasorum.
    • Inverted tree/spider leg collaterals.
    • Severe vasospasm causing corrugated/rippled artery. 
    • Distal runoff is the amount of dye filling in the main vessel distal to the obstruction through collaterals. If the distal run-off is good then ischemia is compensated. If the distal run-off is poor then ischemia is decompensated.

Treatment:

  • Cessation of smoking is the definitive management. 
  • Drugs to improve circulation include
    • Pentoxifylline
    • Aspirin
    • Clopidogrel
    • Statins 
    • Cilostazol- Phosphodiesterase inhibitor is ideally used to improve circulation in the collaterals formed.
    • Vasodilators and anticoagulants have no role in the treatment.
  • Care of limb with Buerger’s exercise and positioning 
  • Surgical management may include lumbar sympathectomy and amputation according to the presenting features.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presents with red violaceous skin lesion with a palpable mass on his forearm. History reveals that this finding has been present since childhood and has been increasing in size. On examination warmth, bruit and thrill are present. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of arteriovenous malformation (AVM). MRI is the investigation of choice for the evaluation and follow-up of peripheral arteriovenous malformations.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offers numerous advantages over both CT and radiographs and has become the most important modality to diagnose arteriovenous malformations. MRI techniques including time-of-flight and phase contrast can be used to isolate inflow blood supply to better predict the risk of ischemia following embolization.

MRI also provides well-defined images defining boundaries between the AVM, surrounding fat, and neurovascular bundles, which is necessary for the planning of surgical or embolic interventions.

On examination, AVM appears as a red/violaceous lesion with a palpable mass under it. Local warmth, bruit, and thrill are present.

Treatment is initiated when signs and symptoms of ischemia, ulceration, bleeding, or hemodynamic instability are present. Surgical management includes arterial embolization to temporarily occlude the AVM followed by surgical extirpation/destruction. The AVM and overlying skin is widely excised followed by reconstruction.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of acquired unilateral hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
Renal stone is the most common cause of acquired unilateral hydronephrosis.

Hydronephrosis is the aseptic dilatation of the kidney caused by obstruction. It is the most common urologic abnormality found on ultrasound evaluation.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

questions.text: For a patient being considered for bariatric surgery, which of the following will you not include when calculating the Obesity Surgery-Mortality risk score (OS-MRS score)?
questions.solution:
Type-2 Diabetes mellitus (DM) is not a component of the Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS).

Edmonton Obesity Staging System (EOSS) and Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS) are used to discuss with patients the likely prognosis without surgery, and the risk of complications.

Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS):

Risk factor Score
Age ≥ 45 yr 1
BMI ≥ 50 1
Male gender 1
Hypertension 1
DVT(Deep Vein Thrombosis)/ PE(Pulmonary Embolism) 1
Risk Category Score Post-op mortality
A (Low) 0-1 0.3

C (High) 4-5 3.2

Note: Uncontrolled diabetes is considered a risk factor, as in any other surgery. However, it is not considered under the OS-MRS scoring system.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with facial weakness and the following sign 4 days after undergoing total thyroidectomy. The probable cause of this condition includes all of the following except:

choices.text: Accidental ligature of inferior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing carpopedal spasm are suggestive of hypocalcemia secondary to postoperative hypoparathyroidism. Thyroid insufficiency does not manifest with hypocalcemia.

Hypoparathyroidism is a rare complication of thyroidectomy which can occur as a transient event or due to the accidental removal of the parathyroid gland or ligation of the inferior thyroid artery. 

A rapid influx of serum calcium into bones in the immediate postoperative period may cause severe hypocalcaemia—hungry bone syndrome. It is more commonly observed in patients with beta-blockers. It is due to a sudden drop in PTH level after surgery.

Mostly it is temporary due to vascular spasm of parathyroid glands, which occurs on the 2nd-5th postoperative day.

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia:

  • Mild circumoral or digital numbness
  • Paresthesia
  • Laryngeal spasms 
  • Cardiac arrhythmias 
  • Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles.
  • Trousseau's sign is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (as shown in the image)
  • Muscle weakness is the earliest feature of hypocalcemia.
  • Convulsions

Serum calcium estimation is done and then 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given intravenously 8th hourly. Later supplemented by oral calcium carbonate 500 mg 8th hourly. After 3–6 weeks, the patient is admitted, the drug is stopped and the serum calcium level is repeated.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with purulent discharge from the umbilicus. He underwent laparoscopic appendicectomy 6 months back. X-ray sinogram of the patient reveals an enterocutaneous fistula tract as shown below. Which of the following aids in the spontaneous closure of the fistula?

choices.text: Foreign body in the fistula tract

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray sinogram showing a fistula tract connecting the skin opening and the small intestine are suggestive of an enterocutaneous fistula. In this case, it is most likely due to the umbilical port used during appendicectomy. 

Fistula track length >2.5 cms is likely to heal. Enterocutaneous fistulas of length <2.5 cm are unlikely to heal and close.

Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified according to their location and volume of daily output. These factors determine the treatment and mortality rates. Proximal fistulas are associated with higher output, greater fluid and electrolyte loss. Distal fistulas tend to have lower output, making them easier to manage and more likely to close spontaneously.

Type of fistula Output/day
High-output fistula >500 mL
Intermediate fistula 200 - 500 mL
Low-output fistula <200 mL

Related Pearl: Factors Preventing Spontaneous Fistula Closure

  • High output (>500 mL/24 hours)
  • Severe disruption of intestinal continuity (>50% of bowel circumference)
  • Active inflammatory bowel disease of bowel segment
  • Cancer
  • Radiation enteritis
  • Distal obstruction
  • Undrained abscess cavity
  • Foreign body in the fistula tract
  • Fistula tract <2.5 cm long
  • Epithelialization of fistula tract

questions.text:
All of the following are indications to perform circumcision in children, except:
  1.   Recurrent balanoposthitis 
  2.   Recurrent UTI with abnormal urinary tract 
  3.   Physiological phimosis (<6yrs of age) 
  4.   Tight frenulum 
  5.   On request
questions.solution:
A tight frenulum and physiological phimosis are not indications of circumcision in children. 

Physiological phimosis is seen in children that are less than 6 years of age (2-6 years) due to natural adhesions between the glans and inner preputial skin. It rectifies on its own. 

Circumcision is the surgical removal of the foreskin that covers the glans penis.

Indications of circumcision in children: 

  • True phimosis (associated with a white, scarred preputial orifice, most common just before puberty)
  • Paraphimosis
  • On request (most common) 
  • Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO)
  • Recurrent UTI with abnormal upper urinary tract
  • Recurrent balanoposthitis

Indications of circumcision in adults: 

  • Recurrent balanitis 
  • Tight frenulum (Splitting of frenulum can occur during sexual activity)
  • Inability to retract the foreskin for intercourse

questions.text: Who comes under category III non-heart-beating donor?

choices.text: A patient who died during transportation to the hospital
A patient who died after failed resuscitation after reaching the hospital
A patient who was brought dead to the hospital
A patient who is awaiting death in the hospital

questions.solution:
Category III donors are patients with non-survivable injuries who have their treatment withdrawn and if such patients wished in life to be organ donors, the transplant team can attend at the time of treatment withdrawal and retrieve organs after cardiac arrest has occurred.

Modified Maastricht classification- Categories of non-heart-beating donors:

 

Category Description Circumstances
Category I Includes victims of accident and suicide who are found dead at the scene and resuscitation is deemed pointless (e.g. fatal cervical spine fracture). Uncontrolled - transplant team not present or prepared 
Category II victims of sudden cardiac or cerebral catastrophe who are brought to emergency departments while being resuscitated by ambulance personnel or who died in the department. Other sources include patients suffering an isolated brain injury, anoxia, and stroke, and victims of major trauma who died soon after hospital admission.
 
Uncontrolled - transplant team not present or prepared    
 
Category III Patients who are dying, often in an intensive care unit. These are the patients awaiting cardiac arrest where the treating clinicians have decided to withdraw treatment and not commence resuscitation for various reasons.

Controlled - transplant team present and prepared

 
 
Category IV Comprises patients who suffer unexpected cardiac arrest during or after the determination of brain death.

Controlled - transplant team present and prepared

 
 

Category V 

 Unexpected cardiac arrest during intensive care -
Uncontrolled - transplant team not present or prepared

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of a neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found on the posterior triangle of the neck, as shown in the image below. The slip sign is negative and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. Which of the following is not a treatment option for this child?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing mass in the posterior triangle of the neck which is fluctuant and brightly transilluminant is suggestive of cystic hygroma. Sistrunk operation is not a treatment option for cystic hygroma. It is the surgery done for a thyroglossal cyst and limb reduction surgeries in patients with lymphedema.

Cystic hygroma/cavernous lymphangioma is a lymph filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development.

Clinically, it presents as a mass in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. On examination, it appears as a soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant since the sac is filled with lymph.

Complications of cystic hygroma include respiratory difficulty, secondary infection, and chylothorax.

Management:

  • Primarily, the treatment includes aspiration (Option B) of the contents. Later once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue, it is excised.
  • Single cysts are treated with sclerosing therapy (Option C). Commonly used sclerosants include OK– 432 which is an inactive strain of group A Streptococcus pyogenes, pure ethanol, interferon α 2a, and doxycycline.
  • Multiple cysts are treated by complete excision of the cyst (Option D).

questions.text: A patient was found to have an adrenal mass during a routine health checkup. What is the most common cause of adrenal mass in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected in imaging studies is incidentaloma. The majority of these lesions are non-functional i.e benign.

Incidentalomas are evaluated to classify them as:

  • Non-functional (75%): most common 
  • Functional: may present with Cushing's syndrome, phaeochromocytoma, Conn's syndrome, etc.
  • Secondary metastasis (2%): from breast, lung, and kidneys are seen in 2% of the patients 

Management of incidentalomas:

  • Non-functional: Tumors with a size <4cm are managed conservatively. MRI surveillance is done every 3-6 months. For size >4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done.

  • Functional tumours: Hormonal assay studies are done in suspected functional tumours or patients presenting with symptoms. If positive, it should be managed accordingly. If not managed, functional tumours can become malignant and the incidence increases 4-fold if the size of the lesion crosses 4 cm.

  • Secondary metastasis: Fine-needle aspiration and biopsy is performed. Tests for pheochromocytoma should always be done before this procedure to avoid precipitating a hypertensive crisis.

questions.text: A newborn is found to have a congenital urethral abnormality as shown in the image. It results in difficulty directing the urine stream. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is true?

choices.text: Dorsal chordee is a common association
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Circumcision should not be performed before corrective surgery

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis suggest hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin will be used for surgical reconstruction.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It occurs due to the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds.

Hypospadias is characterized by: 

  • A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum)
  • Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in hooded foreskin)
  • Ventral chordee (bending of the penis)

Hypospadias can be classified into the following types based on the meatal location:

  • Anterior (distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

The image given below shows classification of hypospadiasis.

Surgery for correction of hypospadias are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 18 months.

Surgery in hypospadias is done to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmetic reasons. Surgery depends on the site of the hypospadias. 

The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include:

  • Orthoplasty - Chordee correction
  • Urethroplasty - To reposition the urethral opening and tubularize urethra
  • Glanuloplasty - Reconstruction of glans
  • Skin cover and scrotoplasty

Complications of hypospadias surgery include:

  • Urethrocutaneous fistula (most common)
  • Recurrence of chordee
  • Urethral stricture
  • Meatal stenosis
  • Infection

Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty is the most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presents with difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids. A barium swallow revealed the following finding. What are all the investigations necessary for the following condition?

1. Timed barium study

2. Endoscopy

3. Esophageal manometry

4. 24-h pH monitoring
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the barium swallow showing a bird beak appearance are suggestive of achalasia cardia. Timed barium study, endoscopy, and esophageal manometry are all necessary investigations for diagnosis of achalasia cardia.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis

On performing a timed barium study, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a bird's beak at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. 

Endoscopy and biopsy are usually carried out to rule out cancer. 

24 hr pH monitoring is used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy
